fact: Fact: Average adult femoral neck shaft angle is 135°
Fact: The femoral neck shaft angle can be measured by placing one line down the center of the femoral shaft and a second line down the center of the femoral neck.
Fact: High femoral neck shaft angle = Valgus Hip  Low femoral neck shaft angle = Varus Hip
Fact: "In a ""normal hip"" the center of the femoral head should be at the same level as the tip of the greater trochanter"
Fact: In a Varus hip, the center of the femoral head is located below the tip of the greater trochanter
Fact: In a Valgus hip, the center of the femoral head is located above the tip of the greater trochanter
Fact: The femoral neck shaft angle affects forces across the hip because it changes the tension of the abductor mechanism
Fact: Most femoral components of a total hip replacement rely on bony ingrowth for long term fixation.
Fact: Bony ingrowth occurs during the first 6 weeks after a THA
Fact: Similar to the fracture healing, THA bony ingrowth requires micromotion < 50 nm for ingrowth to occur, otherwise, fibrous ingrowth occurs.

Fact: For proper THA ingrowth to occur, the press-fit must be obtained at the time of surgery - the implant must fill the proximal canal and place enough hoop stress on the rim of cortical bone to prevent micromotion.
Fact: THA   The best press-fit occurs when the implant design matches the native femoral canal.

Fact: THA   The Dorr Classification is the most commonly used classification system for describing the relationship between the proximal femoral anatomy and the femoral diaphysis, otherwise known as the Canal-Flare Index.
Fact: THA   The Dorr Classification describes the relationship of the diameter of the proximal femoral canal relative to the femoral diaphysis.

Fact: DORR CLASSIFICATION   TYPE A femurs have a thick cortex and narrow canal (referred to as a “champagne flute”) and commonly found in men and younger patients.  It permits good cementless fixation with low risk of fracture, however, selecting the proper implant can be challenging given the metaphyseal-diaphyseal mismatch. A single wedge stem design is often used.
Fact: DORR CLASSIFICATION    TYPE B femurs demonstrate some medial and posterior cortex bone loss, and therefore a wider canal, and are an intermediary between Type A and C.
Fact: DORR CLASSIFICATION   Most femurs are a type B

Fact: DORR CLASSIFICATION   TYPE C femurs demonstrate significant cortical bone loss particularly in the medial and posterior cortex with a capacious canal (referred to as a “stovepipe”), and is common in postmenopausal women and should warn surgeons of concern for cementless fixation, particularly difficulty in controlling rotational motion, and increased risk for intraoperative fracture.
Fact: The Knee is more complex than a simple hinge joint   Motion occurs not only in flexion-extension, but also involves rotation, pivot, and gliding movements
Fact: The medial femoral condyle (MFC)::LFC/MFC of the knee is larger and more circular – meaning a uniform radius of curvature.
Fact: The lateral femoral condyle (LFC)::Lateral/Medial Femoral Condyle of the knee is smaller
Fact: In the LFC::LFC/MFC, the distal condyle and posterior condyle have very different radii of curvature to promote LFC motion during knee flexion
Fact: The MFC::LFC/MFC radius of curvature is relatively uniform and so the MFC remains mostly stationary during knee flexion
Fact: The difference in posterior rollback between the LFC and MFC (LFC rolls back while the MFC remains relatively in place) drives the distal femur to externally::externally/internally rotate
Fact: "The majority of external rotation of the femur occurs in the first 15::#° of knee flexion."
Fact: As the femur flexes, it externally rotates about 15° in relation to the tibia and thus the trochlear groove moves a little laterally::medially/laterally to help with patellar tracking

Fact: Patellar maltracking can occur if the femur doesn’t rotate during flexion or if there is insufficient medial structures (specifically the medial patellofemoral ligament) acting as a harness to guide the patella
Fact: A hypoplastic trochlear groove can lead to patellar subluxation by failing to provide a bumper to guide tracking
Fact: Posterior rollback determines the point of terminal flexion before impingement
Fact: The lateral tibial plateau is flat (or even slightly convex)::dished/flat and is designed this way to encourage LFC roll back during knee flexion
Fact: The medial tibial plateau is dished (concave)::dished/flat, allowing for less MFC rollback, and enabling a pivot type motion whereby the LFC rotates around the stable MFC
Fact: The medial::lateral/medial compartment of the knee has better articular congruence and acts as the pivot point of the knee
Fact: The LFC is smaller, with a variable center of rotation between distal and posterior condyles to encourage more motion

Fact: The superficial::deep/superficial MCL is the major medial stabilizer, originating at the medial epicondyle and traveling deep to the pes muscles to insert broadly on the tibia 4.5 cm distal to the joint line
Fact: The deep::deep/superficial MCL is only a thickening of the capsule (as known as the medial capsular ligament)
Fact: MCL assumes more valgus restraint in knee flexion::extension/flexion

Fact: "The LCL (""fibular collateral ligament"") provides lateral stability, originating proximal::distal/proximal and posterior::anterior/posterior to the lateral epicondyle and inserts on the lateral fibular head"

Fact: "The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) prevents anterior subluxation of the tibia, particularly near terminal extension   ACL is taut around 15::#° of flexion, which corresponds to the region where your quad has the worst mechanical advantage to extend the leg, and thus exerts the greatest anterior directed force on the proximal tibia."
Fact: Cartilage wear occurs in the anterior-medial aspect of the tibia when the ACL is intact::injured/intact
Fact: Cartilage wear occurs in the posterior-medial aspect of the knee when the ACL is injured::injured/intact
Fact: If the tibia subluxes posteriorly as seen in PCL::ACL/PCL injury, the femur is unable to achieve proper posterior rollback, which is essential for achieving terminal flexion

Fact: "The menisci improve joint congruity by smoothing out the difference between relatively round femoral condyles and flat tibial plateaus.   The menisci increase the effective joint surface (a complete meniscectomy reduces the contact area by 50::#%), which reduces contact forces."
Fact: Complete meniscectomy increases joint forces by 2-3x,    20% of people developing significant arthritis in just 3 years 100% of people develop significant arthritis by 20 years
Fact: Over time, the posterior::anterior/posterior horn of the medial meniscus becomes degenerated in people without a(n) ACL
Fact: The Quad is the knee extensor and weakness/atrophy affects patellar tracking and is associated with patellofemoral pain

Fact: The Mechanical Axis of the leg is a line drawn from the center of the hip to the center of the ankle   This line should cross through the center of the knee, meaning the knee has neutral alignment

Fact: The anatomic axis is the center of the bones making up the leg, and the anatomic axis of the femur::femur/tibia is 6° from the mechanical axis    The anatomic axis of the tibia::femur/tibia is in-line with the mechanical axis
Fact: The knee angle is also known as the femoral-tibial angle
Fact: The joint line of the knee is variable person-to-person, however, on average it's in about 3° of varus::valgus/varus on the tibial side (relative to the mechanical axis)
Fact: The tibial articular surface is in 3° varus::valgus/varus to the mechanical axis
Fact: On the femoral side of the knee, the femoral articular surface is in 3° of valgus::valgus/varus
Fact: On the femoral side of the knee joint, the joint line is in 9° of valgus relative to the ANATOMIC::anatomic/mechanical axis
Fact: On the tibial side of the knee, the joint line is in 3° of varus::valgus/varus relative to the anatomic axis
Fact: In a standard TKA, the femoral cuts (all of them)::femoral cuts/tibia cut get adjusted to line up with the tibial cut::femoral cuts/tibia cut
Fact: Knee angles are simplified in TKA by cutting the Tibia Perpendicular to the mechanical/anatomic (both)::mechanical or anatomic axis, which is 0°
Fact: A varus::valgus/varus knee (due to common medial sided DJD) will deviate laterally::laterally/medially with respect to the mechanical axis
Fact: A valgus knee will deviate medially (the knock-kneed appearance on clinical exam)
Fact: Appropriate placement of the acetabular component depends on 4 important things:    version inclination depth height
Fact: The goal of acetabular cup placement is to match the implant's range of motion to:   the native hip's range of motion
Fact: Impingement in THA occurs when our anatomy wants to move the hip beyond what is permitted by the orientation of the implant

Fact: If acetabular impingement occurs with an implant, its like a car hitting a brick wall: motion comes to a halt, and the implant can:   1. dislocate 2. generate wear particles at an accelerated rate
Fact: Neutral version means the cup is facing completely lateral
Fact: Anteversion means the acetabular cup is facing slightly anteriorly
Fact: Retroversion means the acetabular cup is opening up slightly posteriorly
Fact: "The target acetablular cup version is slight anteversion   ""safe zone"" is between 5 and 25 degrees to match native hip motion and avoid impingement"
Fact: Acetabular cup version can be assessed postoperatively by cross leg lateral XR::Specific Imaging
Fact: The goal angle of combined hip anteversion in THA is 35° (+/- 10°)

Fact: True version of pelvis is angle between:   a) the line from the posterior to anterior wall of acetabulum (essentially the ilioischial line) b) a line directly from A to P (this is the alpha angle)
Fact: The expectation for hip ROM after THA is 110 ° flexion and 30 ° extension
Fact: Increasing the acetabular anteversion::anteversion/retroversion in THA increases the flexion::extension/flexion
Fact: "The target acetabular cup inclination is a ""safe zone"" between 30-50° abduction (assessed by AP of hip)"
Fact: Excessive inclination (a vertically oriented acetabular cup) in THA decreases::decreases/increases the surface area of articulation along the superior dome of the cup
Fact: Insufficient inclination (a horizontal acetabular cup) decreases range of motion, but is generally considered less problematic than too much inclination

Fact: Target acetabular cup depth in THA is to recreate the anatomic hip center for that patient by reaming to bleeding cancellous bone   Assessed by AP of hip: cup should be up to, but not past Kohler’s line, aka ilioischial line.

Fact: Over medializing depth of the acetablular cup removes excess bone (always preserve bone, “A.P.B”, is a mantra for TJA surgeons)   However, failure to sufficiently medialize the cup provides less surface area for bony ingrowth
Fact: A lateralized::medialized/lateralized hip center depth shortens the “abductor lever arm” and thus requires the abductors to work harder to counteract the body weight force acting on the hip
Fact: Inferior border of acetabular cup should be at the “tear drop”, assessed by AP of hip

Fact: "The normal hip joint is best understood as a Lever-Arm. The hip center is the fulcrum that sits between 2 opposing forces:    Lever arm #1 is the distance from the hip center to the center of body weight Lever arm #2 is the abductor mechanism, which is distance from the hip center to the greater trochanter (aka the insertion point of our abductors)"
Fact: In a normal hip, the body weight lever arm is 2.5 times longer than the abductor level arm   which means that the abductor force must be 2.5 times stronger than body weight
Fact: Joint reactive forces depend on the activity   Force of walking is 2.5x body weight Force of jogging is 6x body weight Force of running is 8x body weight

Fact: In progressive hip degeneration, the head begins to collapse, the neck shortens::lengthens/shortens, and the abductor mechanism loses tension causing weakness and pain due to increased joint reactive forces.

Fact: Current techniques for hip reconstruction focus on restoring the native anatomical geometry of the hip—placing the acetabular component in a low::high/low and medial::medial/lateral position to restore the center of rotation  and   Selecting a femoral stem that will restore offset by maximizing::maximizing/minimizing tension of the abductors and leg length
Fact: The lumbar spine gains lordosis::lordosis/kyphosis with standing::sitting/standing
Fact: When standing, the lumbar spine gains::gains/loses lordosis and the pelvis decreases::increases/decreases tilt
Fact: When sitting, the lumbar spine loses::gains/loses lordosis and the pelvis increases::decreases/increases tilt
Fact: Pelvic tilt (PT) and sacral slope (SS) are dynamic::dynamic/static pelvic parameters
Fact: Pelvic Incidence = Pelvic tilt + Sacral Slope
Fact: Sacral slope (SS) is dynamic and is the angle of the sacrum. Angle between:   Line 1: line parallel::parallel/perpendicular to sacral promontory Line 2: horizontal reference line
Fact: Pelvic Tilt (PT) is a dynamic angle of the pelvis. Angle between:   Line 1: center of sacral promontory to center of hip Line 2: vertical reference line
Fact: As the upper pelvis moves posterior::anterior/posterior, the pelvic tilt increases, therefore pelvic tilt can be thought of as the degree of pelvic extension.
Fact: The Sacral Slope (SS) and Pelvic Tilt (PT) change by the same amount in a normal flexible spine-sacrum to maintain the Pelvic Incidence
Fact: Sitting after THA risks posterior::anterior/posterior dislocation because of anterior::anterior/posterior impingement as the acetabulum moves anteriorly
Fact: A mobile lumbo-pelvic segment is essential to minimizing THA dislocation
Fact: Lumbar Fusion reduces lumbo-pelvic motion and risks THA dislocation.
Fact: Increasing Pelvic Tilt increases Acetabular Anteversion::anteversion/retroversion

Fact: Increasing Pelvic Tilt Increases Acetabular Anteversion (at a rate of 1.0° pelvic tilt to 0.7° of anteversion), preventing anterior::anterior/posterior impingement, which is important to prevent posterior::anterior/posterior dislocation
Fact: The direct anterior approach to THA is minimally invasive because it is muscle sparing
Fact: Multiple studies suggest that Direct Anterior Approach for THA leads to a(n) early::early/late recovery.

Fact: In comparison to the posterior or antero-lateral approach, the Direct Anterior approach shows:   Improved::improved/worsened postop pain scores Decreased::increased/decreased pain medication Improved::improved/worsened Function Decreased::decreased/increased length of stay

Fact: It is unclear how many weeks postop the Direct Anterior THA approach offers improved outcomes compared to other approaches   Functional outcomes for this approach generally diminish after 6 weeks
Fact: There is a(n) increased rate of femur fracture via the Direct Anterior THA approach

Fact: Direct Anterior THA Approach  Supine on a standard radiolucent table or placed on a specialized table, such as the Hana Table. C-arm fluoroscopy is typically available   On a standard table the pubic symphysis is placed over the break in the table, and a small bump is placed under the coccyx slightly off-center (closer to the operative side).

Fact: Direct Anterior THA Approach     During femoral exposure, a femoral elevator (hook that goes posterior behind the the femur) is fixed to the table and pulls the proximal femur out of the wound, while the table is “opened” foot of table dropped to 45° and the bed is 15° of Trendelenburg
Fact: Posterior Approach to THA gives excellent exposure to:    the entire femur the posterior wall acetabulum
Fact: The Posterior THA approach has a low::high/low risk for Femoral Cortex injury
Fact: Goals of stem placement in THA are to:   1) restore medial offset 2) restore leg length (read: vertical height) 3) restore femoral anteversion (average 15 degrees)
Fact: In THA, Medial offset should be determined by templating (some patients require standard offset, others require high offset - aka greater medial offset)

Fact: The advantage of high medial offset in THA is that it lateralizes the center of the femoral stem and therefore places greater tension on the abductor mechanism, giving greater stability to the implant.
Fact: The disadvantage of high offset in THA is that it can place excessive tension on the abductors and cause trochanteric bursitis.
Fact: Vertical height in THA is determined by where the center of the femoral head sits
Fact: "Vertical height in THA can be increased if the stem doesn't fully sit properly (referred to as a ""potted stem"")"
Fact: Vertical height in THA can be increased if the stem is put into valgus (tip of the stem touches the medial cortex of the femur)

Fact: In THA, Vertical height can be Increased via +4, +8 etc femoral head (although putting on a +4 femoral head increases the neck length +4, so it affects both the medial offset and the vertical height as a calculation of SOH-CAH-TOA).

Fact: Femoral Anteversion is about 15 degrees, but the native anatomy of the femur often dictates the version for a press-fit stem (for a cemented stem, or an S-ROM stem, the surgeon has much more control over the femoral version).  Many surgeons use the posterior cortex of the femur, at the femoral neck cut, as their guide for setting version.
Fact: If you see the entire lesser trochanter on AP pelvis xray, the femur is externally rotated

Fact: Press-fit can occur at the:  1) Metaphysis - the standard for primary hip replacements 2) Meta-diaphysis - when someone is very osteoporotic and the surgeon is not sure if they can rely purely on the softer metaphyseal bone for rigid fixation 3) Diaphysis - the standard for revision hip replacements, when the metaphyseal bone is gone

Fact: The technique to prepare the femoral canal for the stem implant in THA utilizes broaching alone for the metaphyseal fitting stems, and utilizes reaming for the meta-diaphysial and diaphysial fitting stems.
Fact: In THA, broaching prepares the metaphysis, while reaming prepares the diaphysis.
Fact: GOALS OF PRESS-FIT THA  Short-term - Rigidity Mid-term - Biologic Fixation Long-term - Balanced stress distribution across the femur
Fact: A good landmark for tibial rotation in TKA is to align the anterior aspect of the tibial component with the medial 1/3 of the patellar tendon.
Fact: Cutting the Distal Femur in TKA affects 3 things:   1) Mechanical Alignment 2) Extension gap 3) Joint Line Height
Fact: The goal is to place the TKA in neutral mechanical alignment
Fact: The difference between the anatomic axis of the femur and the mechanical axis is about 6°, and that is commonly what the intramedullary guide is set to.
Fact: The hole for the intramedullary femoral guide in TKA should be drilled just above the PCL and aimed down the medullary canal
Fact: If the TKA extension gap is trapezoidal, this indicates soft tissue imbalance that requires adjustment.
Fact: The DEPTH of the distal femur for the femoral implant of every company (and therefore the target depth for ALL distal femoral cuts) is 9 mm
Fact: In TKA, the Anterior Femoral Cut is thru the trochlear groove and the depth of this cut affects the patellofemoral joint
Fact: In TKA, the Posterior Femoral Cut is thru the posterior condyle and the depth of this cut affects the flexion gap.
Fact: In TKA, Anterior and Posterior Femoral Cuts are parallel and together they determine the rotation of the femoral implant.
Fact: In TKA, the Femoral Implant Size must be determined with a sizing guide, and is based off the A-P Diameter::Measurement
Fact: Internal rotation of either the femoral or tibial component of 1-4° in TKA causes some lateral patellar tilt/tracking
Fact: Internal rotation of either the femoral or tibial component of 5-8° in TKA causes patellar subluxation and pain
Fact: Internal rotation of either the femoral or tibial component of >8° in TKA causes dislocation and failure
Fact: Not only does the Flexion Gap need to be rectangular (indication of rotation), but it also needs to be the same size as the Extension Gap (9 mm).
Fact: The benefit of Posterior Referencing is that you recreate the normal Posterior Condyle Offset
Fact: In TKA, the posterior condylar offset is important because its directly related to the arc of motion before impingement occurs

Fact: In TKA Posterior Referencing, if the femoral component is measured “too big” then the anterior cut will be too shallow, causing the patellofemoral joint to become too tight in flexion (knee stiffness in flexion)

Fact: "In TKA Posterior Referencing, if the femoral component is measured ""too small"", the anterior cut will be too deep, and will cause “notching”, which may increase risk for periprosthetic fracture."

Fact: In TKA Anterior Referencing, if the femur is big relative to the size of the 4-in-1 guide, you will end up removing too much bone posteriorly, which will decrease the Posterior Condyle Offset and may reduce range of motion

Fact: In TKA Anterior Referencing, if the femur is small relative to the size of the 4-in-1 guide, you will end up removing too little bone posteriorly, and the Flexion Gap will be small relative to the Extension gap.
Fact: Across most device companies, the standard thickness of the Patellar Button is 9 mm. Therefore, the standard patellar cut should be 9::(Same) mm.
Fact: It's important to avoid cutting the patella too thin because there is an increased risk of fracture and higher rate of AVN when the patella is cut to < 12 mm of native patella.
Fact: If the medial or lateral compartment is looser in TKA, this side will experience less tension and may lead to an unstable TKA and/or asymmetric wear and early failure.
Fact: In TKA, trapezoidal flexion and extension gaps occur despite perfect bone cuts because of soft tissue imbalance
Fact: Ranawat Valgus Class I  Knee Angle (Femoral-Tibial Angle): <10o MCL Status: Intact
Fact: Ranawat Valgus Class II  Knee Angle (Femoral-Tibial Angle): 10-20o MCL Status: Attenuated but has a firm endpoint
Fact: Ranawat Valgus Class III  Knee Angle (Femoral-Tibial Angle): >20o MCL Status: Absent or Severely Attenuated
Fact: There is a risk of recurrent Valgus deformity after primary TKA when the MCL is deficient and a(n) primary insert is used

Fact: In TKA, if the MCL is completely absent, a hinge prosthesis should be considered as excessive stress to a constrained insert may cause significant wear, early loosening, and post fracture::3 things.
Fact: When performing lateral releases in TKA, the peroneal nerve is at risk between the IT band and Popliteus at the level of the tibial cut.
Fact: In the case of a hypoplastic LFC in TKA (seen with Valgus knees), the posterior referencing system may need to dial in 5° or more to prevent internal rotation of the femoral component.
Fact: In TKA, if there is > 5 mm of deficient bone on the posterior or distal femoral cut, augments should be considered because a cement mantle this large will lead to early loosening.
Fact: The patella engages the trochlear groove in 20° flexion, as the knee continues to flex the entire patella engages and the patella translates laterally and tilts medially.

Fact: Patella is at greatest risk of dislocating in 30° flexion (as it begins to engage)::Degrees flexion/extension, and with further flexion, bony constraint (anterior flange of LFC) prevents lateral instability

Fact: Normally, the patella engages the trochlear groove at 15° flexion, enters the intercondylar notch at X°, but in the case of Patella Baja (elevated joint line) the patella enters the intercondylar notch earlier in flexion and impinges on the polyethylene insert causing pain, osteolysis, and limits flexion.
Fact: The joint line of the knee is approximately:   10 mm above the fibular head 25 mm below the lateral epicondyle 35 mm below the medial epicondyle
Fact: Since the Native Tibia joint line is in Slight Varus (~3o), we resect more from the LATERAL side during the Tibial Cuts in TKA
